ygData.subject: New Paper Details HyperNEAT Transfer in Keepaway
ygData.msgSnippet: Phillip Verbancsics and I are pleased to announce our new publication, Evolving Static Representations for Task Transfer, in the Journal of Machine Learning

Subject: New Paper Details HyperNEAT Transfer in Keepaway
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=1cPVP7MbbqfX9tYJWogfJ_JjCcruOWrZZicrHw4ENwLbkaWyruW9

Phillip Verbancsics and I are pleased to announce our new publication, "Evo=
lving Static Representations for Task Transfer," in the Journal of Machine =
Learning Research (JMLR) on HyperNEAT in simulated RoboCup Keepaway:

http:=
//eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/verbancsics.jmlr10.html

This paper si=
gnificantly expands on the transfer experiments in our GECCO paper, includi=
ng not only experiments in transfer to different team sizes, but different =
field sizes and field resolutions as well.  In general it shows how HyperNE=
AT's capability to input and output at higher resolutions (i.e. higher dime=
nsionalities) than regular neural networks translates into an new ability t=
o transfer without changing representation.  It is compared to several well=
-known reinforcement learning algorithms.  By publishing in JMLR on a well-=
established reinforcement learning benchmark (i.e. RoboCup Keepaway) we are=
 once again hoping to bring ideas in indirect encoding to wider audiences t=
han the traditional evolutionary computation and GDS communities.

Videos o=
f evolved HyperNEAT Keepaway behavior described in the paper are also avail=
able at:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperneat-keepaway.html

ken
